Description: Programs as statements that directly change computed state (datafields)
Main traits: Direct assignments, common data structure, global variable
Critique: Edsger W. Dijkstra, Michael A. Jackson
Examples: C, C++, Java, Kotlin, PHP, Python, Ruby

Description: A style of imperative programming with more logical program structure
Main traits: Structogram, indentation, no or limited use of goto statements
Examples: C, C++, Java, Kotlin, Pascal,PHP, Python

Description: Derived from structured programming, based on the concept of modular programming or the procedure call
Main traits: Local variable, sequence, selection, iteration, and modularization

Description: Treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions avoiding state and mutable data
Main traits: Lambda calculus, compositionality, formula, recursion, referential transparency, no side effects
Examples: C++, Clojure, Coffeescript, Elixir, Erlang, F#, Haskell, Java (since version 8), Kotlin, Lisp, Python, R, Ruby, Scala, SequenceL, Standard ML, JavaScript, Elm

Description: Control flow is determined mainly by events, such as mouse click or interrupts including timer
Main traits: Main loop, event handlers, asynchronous processes

Description: Treats datafields as objects manipulated through predefined methods only
Main traits: Objects, methods, message passing, information hiding, data abstraction, encapsulation, polymorphism, inheritance, serialization-marshalling
Examples: Common Lisp, C++, C#, Eiffel, Java, Kotlin, PHP, Python, Ruby, Scala, JavaScript

Description: Defines program logic, but not detailed control flow
Main traits: Fourth-generation languages, spreadsheet, report program generator
Examples: SQL, regular expression, Prolog, OWL, SPARQL

Description: Treats programs as a model of a finite state machine or any other formal automata
Main traits: State enumeration, control variable, state changes, isomorphism, state transition table
